persona.name: Jesse Banwart - Experience Strategist & UX Researcher
persona.summary: A seasoned UX professional who transitioned from UX design to experience strategy at Deloitte, with a strong focus on research. Jesse combines academic training in human factors and business with a passion for uncovering surprising insights that challenge stakeholder assumptions. He values integrity in research and emphasizes the importance of thorough planning and stakeholder management.
persona.image_prompt: Professional male in his early 30s in a modern office setting, dressed business casual, engaged in a collaborative session at a digital whiteboard. The scene should show him leading a research planning session with stakeholders, gesturing towards research findings displayed on screen. Expression should convey confidence and enthusiasm while maintaining professionalism.

demographics.education: Master's in Human Factors with MBA component

persona.background: Started with a unique foundation in architecture-focused education programs before pursuing a master's degree combining human factors and MBA studies. Transitioned from UX design to experience strategy at Deloitte, where he's been for the past three years. His early research experience was characterized by scrappy, guerrilla-style methods, which evolved into more formalized approaches in his professional career.

goals.goal: Uncover surprising insights that challenge assumptions
goals.motivation: Help stakeholders see beyond their existing knowledge and constraints
supporting_quotes: Surprising people surprising people uhâ€¦ information that they really that was right in front of their face all the time, but never really made sense to them
I think there's a very human desire in a lot of scenarios to like default to what you know and not really allow yourself to think um in the abstract

goals.motivation: Ensure confidence in research findings and recommendations
supporting_quotes: I definitely think integrity is a huge key principle, like making sure that you're just that you believe everything that you're presenting is, I think, a huge huge part of what like makes me okay with the work that we do

goals.goal: Streamline research planning and approval processes
goals.motivation: Reduce time spent on administrative tasks to focus on valuable research
supporting_quotes: Typically, it's an approval like it's in putting together a plan and like explaining it to people and getting people on board with it and making edits
You usually have to spend a couple of weeks getting approval, talking to people, making sure the test is right

pain_points.impact: Delays project timelines and reduces time for actual research
supporting_quotes: Why is this taking like a month and a half? And why is it so expensive?
You usually have to spend a couple of weeks getting approval, talking to people, making sure the test is right

pain_points.impact: Forces manual synthesis work and increases time spent on analysis
supporting_quotes: Right now, it's really unreliable and not very good. I think in three years, they'll get a lot better at it
designers too can have kind of a little bit of an ego around what they've put together... very quick to be like, well, there was a problem with your study
we'll spend 15 minutes after that interview externalizing. So we'll be in a board. We'll say, okay, they said this, that, the other. Here's their pain points
We'll host a research question ideation session that's an hour long
We'll look at any designs that have been put together. The current experience will pull all those screenshots into a fig jam
I like in fig jam, they have like built out calendars and I like to time block in a calendar to help understand

technology.comfort_level: High proficiency with research and collaboration tools
supporting_quotes: we use tools in every every asset even so mu iq like even though there's a lot of built-in stuff with it, a lot of times we're exporting that out to Excel
We usually build those out in Figma nowadays
I think automated synthesis will be a lot better... I think in three years, they'll get a lot better at it
You usually have to spend a couple of weeks getting approval, talking to people, making sure the test is right
I think there will always there will be a better push in the tools that we use towards a centralized insights repository

preferences.reason: Better suited for deep insights and understanding
supporting_quotes: I do mostly qualitative. So for a lot of what we do, we are in the like 15 to 50 participant range

preferences.reason: Ensures alignment and better research outcomes
supporting_quotes: We'll host a research question ideation session that's an hour long
We'll walk through them one at a time. We'll call out, hey, do you think this works?

opportunities.impact: Reduce time spent on manual analysis and documentation
opportunities.implementation: Develop AI-powered tools that can generate initial insights and presentations from research data

opportunities.impact: Faster research execution and reduced administrative overhead
opportunities.implementation: Create standardized templates and processes for research planning and approval

opportunities.impact: Better leverage of existing research and insights
opportunities.implementation: Implement a searchable repository of research findings and insights that can be queried for new projects

analyst_notes: Jesse represents a modern UX researcher who values both rigor and efficiency in research. His background in both design and business gives him a unique perspective on research value. Key themes from his interview include: the importance of integrity in research, the desire to uncover non-obvious insights, frustration with current tool limitations, and a strong emphasis on stakeholder management. His vision for the future of research tools, particularly around automated synthesis and centralized insights, provides valuable direction for tool development.
